32#ifndef _ASM_UACCESS_H_
33#define _ASM_UACCESS_H_
34
35#include <sys/types.h>
36#include <sys/errno.h>
37#include <sys/systm.h>
38
39/* XXX This is a cop-out. */
40#define VERIFY_READ 0
41#define VERIFY_WRITE 1
42static inline bool
43access_ok(int verify_op __unused, const void *uaddr __unused,
44 size_t nbytes __unused)
45{
46 return true;
47}
48
49#define __copy_from_user copy_from_user
50#define __copy_to_user copy_to_user
51
52static inline int
53copy_from_user(void *kernel_addr, const void *user_addr, size_t len)
54{
55 /* XXX errno NetBSD->Linux */
56 return -copyin(user_addr, kernel_addr, len);
57}
58
59static inline int
60copy_to_user(void *user_addr, const void *kernel_addr, size_t len)
61{
62 /* XXX errno NetBSD->Linux */
63 return -copyout(kernel_addr, user_addr, len);
64}
65
66#define get_user(KERNEL_LOC, USER_ADDR) \
67 copy_from_user(&(KERNEL_LOC), (USER_ADDR), sizeof(KERNEL_LOC))
68
69#define put_user(KERNEL_LOC, USER_ADDR) \
70 copy_to_user((USER_ADDR), &(KERNEL_LOC), sizeof(KERNEL_LOC))
71
72#if 0
73/*
74 * XXX These `inatomic' versions are a cop out, but they should do for
75 * now -- they are used only in fast paths which can't fault but which
76 * can fall back to slower paths that arrange things so faulting is OK.
77 */
78
79static inline int
80__copy_from_user_inatomic(void *kernel_addr __unused,
81 const void *user_addr __unused, size_t len __unused)
82{
83 return -EFAULT;
84}
85
86static inline int
87__copy_to_user_inatomic(void *user_addr __unused,
88 const void *kernel_addr __unused, size_t len __unused)
89{
90 return -EFAULT;
91}
92#endif /* 0 */
93
94static inline int
95__copy_from_user_inatomic_nocache(void *kernel_addr __unused,
96 const void *user_addr __unused, size_t len __unused)
97{
98 return -EFAULT;
99}
100
101#endif /* _ASM_UACCESS_H_ */
102
